message: Today, I was sworn in as U.S. Senator for the 115th Congress. It is an honor and privilege to serve and represent the people of the Great State of Idaho. #idahome #idpol

Shortly before Congress went into recess, I joined a bipartisan group of my colleagues in writing the incoming Trump Administration to express our support for the Federal Aviation Administration’s Contract Tower Program.  One of the most successful examples of partnerships between federal and local governments and the private sector, contract towers play a critical role in ensuring the safety and security of commercial and general aviation in Idaho, and in doing so, save taxpayers roughly $200 million annually.  I look forward to working with the Trump Administration and my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to ensure that the Contract Tower Program continues to enhance aviation safety and remains cost effective to the American taxpayer.

Congratulations to Idaho National Laboratorys for being named a 2017 Digital Edge winner by IDG Enterprise for its High Performance Computing immersive 3D visualization capabilities.   https://www.inl.gov/article/idaho-national-laboratory-wins-award-for-immersive-3d-visualization-capability/

My Boise, Twin Falls, Pocatello and Idaho Falls offices remain closed today due to severely hazardous driving conditions.  I will continue to update this page as conditions improve and as offices reopen.  If you would still like to speak to my staff regarding issues before the federal government, you may call my D.C. office at 202-224-6142.  If you are in need of assistance with a federal agency, please visit my website: http://www.crapo.senate.gov/services/personal_assistance.cfm.

I joined Senators Lisa Murkowski and Jim Risch, along with 23 other Senate colleagues, to introduce legislation to reform the National Monument designation process.  This bill would provide greater transparency in the designation process and allow Idahoans’ voices to be heard.  Members of local communtiies must have the ability to provide greater input on such proposals.” http://www.energy.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/1/26-senators-introduce-bill-to-reform-monument-designation-process
Tune in to @PBS tonight @ 7PM MT/6PM PT to see how @INL is helping to innovate nuclear energy. #NuclearOption

Idaho National Laboratory was selected to help lead the U.S. Department of Energy's new Reducing Embodied Energy and Decreasing Emissions (REMADE) Institute.  REMADE is part of the the DOE’s Manufacturing USA effort, which is focused on driving down the cost of technologies needed to reuse, recycle and remanufacture materials.    http://www.postregister.com/articles/news-todays-headlines/2017/01/05/inl-help-lead-manufacturing-efficiency-institute

Today, as a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, I questioned Attorney General-designee Senator Jeff Sessions about states’ rights, federal agency overreach and federal abuse of power. Video at: https://goo.gl/AS8RYX

Today, with Senators Sheldon Whitehouse, Jim Risch, Cory Booker, Lisa Murkowski, and Senator Orrin Hatch, I reintroduced the Nuclear Energy Innovation Capabilities Act (NEICA), which fosters public-private partnerships with the U.S. Department of Energy to accelerate innovation in nuclear energy.  Senator Jim Risch and I celebrated this occasion with Idaho National Laboratory's Deputy Lab Director, Dr. Kelly Beierschmitt. #InnovateNuclearNow

These are the #IdahoTop5 issues Idahoans contacted me about this week. Visit my website to learn more or to contact me regarding another issue important to you: http://www.crapo.senate.gov/issues/constituent_letters.cfm

“We are appreciative of Sen. Crapo’s willingness to stand alongside lawful American gun owners, hunters, and shooting sports enthusiasts.” – National Shooting Sports Foundation | NSSF  senior vice president and general counsel, Lawrence Keane.    The Hearing Protection Act will enable gun owners to have better access to hearing protection products and improve safety for the shooting sports by removing extensive wait times for burdensome paperwork processing that does not advance public safety. http://www.nssfblog.com/nssf-praises-sen-mike-crapo-introduction-of-the-hearing-protection-act-of-2017/
We're less than 24 hours from #Inauguration2017! Many Idahoans have already picked up their tickets from my office. Reminder: all tickets must be picked up by 5:30pm today!
My full statement on today's Inauguration of President Donald J. Trump.  http://www.crapo.senate.gov/media/newsreleases/release_full.cfm?id=363003

In 2016, the Annual Homeless Assessment Report revealed that 12 percent of Idaho’s homeless population were veterans who had bravely fought to protect our nation’s freedoms.  The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development will again conduct its annual assessment to count the number of homeless Americans, including veterans, on January 25, 2017.  The Point-in-Time Count (PIT) reflects the number of homeless Americans at a given point in time.  HUD will report the findings to Congress.     I’ve provided the contact information for the Idahoans directing homelessness services and conducting the PIT.  Please feel free to contact them to learn how to help or to learn more information about the count.  The report will be helpful in informing policy decisions as I continue working on efforts to end homelessness, especially among veterans.
Great to see fellow Idahoans, Governor C. L. "Butch" Otter and First Lady Lori Otter, in D.C. today to discuss the needs of Idahoans. #IDpol #IDinDC
The view from where I sit as we just witnessed the peaceful transfer of power between administrations. We welcome you, President Donald Trump. #Inauguration2017
Photos shared by Idahoans who attended the 58th Presidential Inauguration of the 45th President of the United States, Donald John Trump.

When I presented Brett Waters the Spirit of Freedom Award in November, the Veterans Mobility program had repaired and restored 105 wheelchairs and donated them to veterans and veteran families.  Through their dedication, Frank, Brett and the entire group of volunteers are now up to 120 wheelchair donations.  Congratulations!  Keep up the good work.
University of Idaho Extension 4-H Youth Development in DC

Joined my colleagues Senator Tom Udall, Senator Jim Risch, Senator Martin Heinrich and Senator Michael Bennet in re-introducing the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA) (S. 197).  RECA would allow victims exposed to airborne radiation during nuclear weapons tests in the 1950s and 1960s to file claims under the Act.  Residents in Idaho, Colorado, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico and Utah would be eligible to file for relief under the program if they can show they were harmed by the arms testing.  It’s time we expanded this program for Idahoans and our neighbors. http://crapo.senate.gov/media/newsreleases/release_full.cfm?id=363005
Reminder, tonight is the 2017 PIT count conducted by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. Contact Idaho regional coordinators to learn more.
Congratulations to Idahoans Kathy Min and Ian Muir for being selected to the United States Senate Youth Program! Senator Jim Risch and I look forward to seeing you in March.

I joined my Senate colleagues, Senator Rand Paul, Senator Jerry Moran, U.S. Senator Dean Heller, Senator Orrin Hatch, Senator Jim Inhofe, Senator Steve Daines and Senator Pat Roberts to reintroduce legislation that protects law-abiding Social Security beneficiaries from being stripped of their Second Amendment rights. http://www.crapo.senate.gov/media/newsreleases/release_full.cfm?id=363006

I was pleased to work with Trevor Schaefer to introduce and finally pass Trevor’s Law to better track cancer clusters across the country. Wrapping up a busy #DayInDC after meeting with many Idahoans in my Washington, D.C., office.  Idahoans shared their thoughts with me today regarding veterans’ issues, sustainable county funding, small business interests, Parkinson’s research, juvenile diabetes research, advocacy for Idaho’s sugarbeet farmers, and even more. My weekly meetings in DC are important for me to hear first-hand the needs of Idahoans as your U.S. Senator. Thank you all for visiting and sharing your thoughts and concerns with me.  I look forward to tomorrow’s visits.

First Lady Melania Trump announced today that the lottery to attend the 139th White House Easter Egg Roll will open today at 12pm ET. This year's Easter Egg Roll will take place on Monday, April 17, 2017, outside of the White House. The lottery is free of charge, and winners will be notified via email on Friday, March 31, 2017. The lottery will be available at this website: https://www.recreation.gov/marketing.do?goto=acm/The_White_House_Easter_Egg_Roll.htm&contractCode=NRSO&parkId=117739

This week, former Congresswoman Dr. Heather Wilson visited to discuss her nomination to be Secretary United States Air Force. I appreciated the opportunity to learn more about her vision for the Air Force and to highlight the accomplishments of  the fine men and women serving our nation as Mountain Home Air Force Base Gunfighters and at Gowen Field.  I also expressed my strong support for Gowen Field’s candidacy for a F-35 Joint Strike Fighter mission and invited Dr. Wilson to experience Idaho’s beautiful airspace and Air Force installations firsthand, once confirmed.

ALERT FOR VETERANS: U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs has identified a fraudulent phone number that has been created to mimic the Veterans Choice Program (VCP) phone line.   If a VCP phone line directs you to enter your credit card information on the pretense of receiving a $100 rebate, please DO NOT provide your information. More information about the fraudulent line and the correct VCP access phone number are in the attached photo.

Today marks 55 years of recognizing May 15 as Peace Officers Memorial Day and the week-long recognition as #NationalPoliceWeek.  Today, we pay tribute to peace officers across the country who have lost their lives or have become disabled in the line of duty.  Every day law enforcement officers put their lives on the line to keep us safe, while their families wait each day for their safe return home.  These courageous men and women and their families are a central part of our communities, and I thank them for their commitment to keeping Idahoans and all Americans safe from harm.  Seen here, the Idaho Peace Officers' Memorial is located in Meridian, Idaho, on the grounds of the Idaho State Police Headquarters.

Idaho Attorney General Lawrence Wasden, chairman of the Medal of Honor Commission, will award three Idaho police officers, one posthumously, with the Idaho Medal of Honor today at 2PM MDT in the Idaho Capitol.  The Idaho Medal of Honor is the highest honor bestowed upon law enforcement by the state of Idaho for their courage in the name of public safety.
On Armed Forces Day, we thank all the men and women in uniform for their service to our country.
Congratulations to the Boise VA Medical Center for receiving Practice Greenhealth's Greenhealth Emerald Award!

Today I met with leaders at the Lewiston Orchards Irrigation District.  They have developed a collaborative solution for new water sources to assist salmon species while preserving water for domestic uses in the Lewiston area.
Met with members of the Clearwater Basin Collaborative yesterday in Orofino.

Today I presented Dr. Dan Prinzing of the Wassmuth Center for Human Rights a Congressional Record Statement honoring Idahoans for standing against hate speech in the recent vandalism at the Anne Frank Memorial in Boise. The Memorial is the only one of its kind in the U.S.  Idahoans have united together to contribute tens of thousands of dollars to repair the vandalism and expand human rights education at the site.  Rather than responding with anger and hate, Idaho is moving forward with a positive spirit of renewal and inclusiveness.  I was joined by Boise Mayor Dave Bieter, Idaho State Senators Cherie Buckner-Webb and Chuck Winder, Idaho Representatives Hy Kloc and Mat Erpelding, and students from Hailey.

June is #PTSDAwarenessMonth.  Tomorrow, I’ll be joining experts in the veterans community in Twin Falls to discuss and share information about PTSD.  I will also sign a pledge to help raise PTSD Awareness throughout the month of June. https://www.crapo.senate.gov/media/newsreleases/veterans-ptsd-issues-raised-at-twin-falls-event
NA
Yesterday, I joined Payette Mayor Jeff Williams and Librarian Erin Haley to hand out books to students in Payette. The books are made available through the The Library of Congress.

Yesterday I joined experts in the veterans community in Twin Falls to discuss PTSD.  I signed a pledge to help raise PTSD Awareness throughout the month of June.  Raising awareness is essential to overcoming misinformation surrounding PTSD and to providing support for veterans, their families and all others who have experienced trauma to get care.

I signed a pledge with the National Center for PTSD - U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to raise awareness throughout the month of June.  As part of my pledge, each of my state offices will have a designated information table about PTSD.  The displays—all similar to the one pictured here from my Twin Falls office—will contain information on understanding the basics of PTSD, learning where and how to get help, and how others can give support.

#tbt Last Friday, I lead a panel to discuss PTSD and the importance of care for those who have put their lives on the line. Thank you to members of the Boise VA Medical Center, the Boise Vet Center, Idaho National Guard, and Mountain Home Air Force Base Gunfighters for joining me in discussing this important matter. (via Times-News) http://magicvalley.com/news/local/crapo-leads-panel-to-speak-on-ptsd-veterans-services/article_5cb6bab1-a7f3-5915-8a3b-545a544bcaec.html

ICYMI: I introduced the Veterans Health Administration Reform Act to streamline and improve health care for veterans.  I told veterans I would continue to press for sensible reforms at the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs​ and this measure addresses some of the underlying problems that made the Veterans Choice Program so difficult for veterans and the VA.
This #PTSDAwarenessMonth, understand key information about PTSD. Visit the National Center for PTSD website for more information: www.ptsd.va.gov

The removal of the ban of U.S. beef exports to China is long overdue.  This extended ban on U.S. beef imports was unnecessary and placed American ranchers at a competitive disadvantage.  Idaho, as well as ranchers nationwide, will again have access to China's strong market and growing demand for quality American beef. https://www.crapo.senate.gov/media/newsreleases/idaho-us-beef-producers-regain-exports-to-china

I was compelled to introduce the Shauna Hill Post-9/11 Education Benefits Transferability Act with my friend and colleague, Senator Jim Risch.  I thank the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs for allowing me to provide a statement for the record on this crucial measure at its legislative hearing yesterday.  Veterans must be able to transfer their hard-earned education benefits from one dependent to another in the event that one dependent passes.

Kindness, support and respect run deep in Idaho.  Hateful acts like these are reprehensible.  I have said it before concerning domestic violence and I’ll say it again, we all have a responsibility to speak out and stop these kinds of acts.  I commend those who are countering the hateful vandalism with kindness.  We should continue to move forward together with positive spirits of renewal and inclusiveness.

The Harry W. Colmery Veterans Education Assistance Act, or “Forever GI Bill,” passed 405-0 in the House of Representatives on Monday, and was advanced by the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs to the full Senate yesterday.  The legislation includes a provision I introduced as standalone legislation in the Senate named for Idahoan, Shauna Hill, and would allow veterans to transfer their hard-earned education benefits from one dependent to another in the event one dependent dies.  Rep. Raúl R. Labrador led the charge for Shauna Hill’s family in the House.  I look forward to working with my colleagues in making sure this legislation passes the full Senate when it comes up for a vote.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/07/25/new-gi-bill-unanimously-passes-house-heads-to-senate/?utm_term=.6ee7bc03fd88

I support Leader McConnell.  Senators are all individually powerful.  There will always be differing and strong opinions on key issues.  Mitch does the yeoman’s job under these very difficult circumstances.

Yesterday's tragedy in Virginia was the result of domestic terrorism. I condemn and reject the racism and hate perpetuated by white supremacist groups. In the wake of this horrific tragedy, let us gather in solidarity with those who lost loved ones and draw closer the families whose lives have been forever shattered by Saturday's events. As others and I noted during a recent gathering at the Anne Frank memorial, Idaho and our nation, are too great for hate.

I congratulate Micron Technology on the ribbon-cutting event today to open what is being called the finest tech research and development facility in the Western Hemisphere.  The new facility on the Boise campus will host a giant cleanroom for research.

Tomorrow, the Wassmuth Center for Human Rights will host its 15th anniversary community celebration of the Anne Frank Human Rights Memorial beginning at 11:30am MDT.  Following the anniversary celebration, a groundbreaking ceremony will be held for the Marilyn Shuler Classroom for Human Rights. http://wassmuthcenter.org/event/free-15th-anniversary-community-celebration-of-the-anne-frank-human-rights-memorial-marilyn-shuler-classroom-groundbreaking-ceremony/

Today marks the 15th anniversary of the Wassmuth Center for Human Rights' Anne Frank Memorial in Boise.  The only memorial to Anne Frank in the United States, it is a place where locals and visitors can consider and reflect on human rights and inspire engagement with others about the issue.  The thought-provoking statue includes excerpts of Anne Frank’s diary and other inspiring quotes to elicit kindness, support and respect for our fellow human beings.  Idaho has a long history of combating racism and discrimination, making strides in human rights for over a century.  Partnering with organizations and efforts across the state that advocate for the worth and dignity of all individuals has been an important part of my time in public service.

Today I joined my Idaho colleagues Rep. Raúl R. Labrador and Senator Jim Risch to present the Congressional Award to outstanding Idaho youth who have set and achieved challenging personal goals. Their leadership in their local communities is admirable. #idpol #idahome

I met with Caldwell High School TRiO Upward Bound students and Caldwell mayor Garret Nancolas today. Each of these exceptional students will have a unique opportunity to experience college courses even before they leave high school. They are already leaders in their school and making great strides in the pursuit of postsecondary education. I look forward to the positive impact they will have on their communities and on their future successes.

Today I presented a Congressional Record Statement to family members of survivors and POWs of the December 1941 attack an imprisonment at Wake Island. Survivors of the defense of Wake Island and their families have held annual reunions and other get togethers for the last nearly 71 years. Many of these gatherings have been organized by Alice Ingham, whose husband was on Wake Island. The last worker from Idaho, Joe Goicoechea, passed away this past year and the last reunion will be held this September. I've introduced legislation with Senator Joe Manchin (WV) to create a new Congressional Gold Medal in honor and memory of those who fought in defense of Guam, Wake Island and the Philippine Archipelago, and who died or were imprisoned in related efforts.

I joined a 4th grade class from Lincoln Elementary in Twin Falls today to read "Whistle for Willie." The students showed me how they could whistle and my office donated books to the school library from The Library of Congress surplus books program.

Governor Andrus was a dynamic and effective leader who knew how to wield authority and get things done for Idaho, and for the nation.  His leadership and sense of purpose as a public servant were demonstrated repeatedly during his long career in public service. He earned my respect, and I count him as a friend.  He will be forever remembered as a leader of great accomplishment. I send my heartfelt sympathies to his family as they, along with Idaho, mourn his passing.
Joined members of the Idaho American Nuclear Society at the Idaho National Laboratory this morning to discuss nuclear energy issues before Congress.

Today I met with individuals at Eastern Idaho Public Health to discuss issues of concern to Idahoans. We discussed the Maternal, Infant, and Early Childhood Home Visiting (MlECHV) Program, which provides evidence-based home  visitation services to mothers and at­ risk youth in order to improve health outcomes, prepare children for academic success, reduce domestic violence , decrease rates of children entering the juvenile justice system, increase family economic self­ sufficiency, and enhance coordination between local community resources.

Lots of Idahoans at an event to honor Vietnam Veterans in Jerome today. Thank you to all those who have served and who continue to serve in our nation's military. Thank you also to those in uniform in our communities who keep us safe every single day.

Today I recognized Scouts from Troop 7 of the  Snake River Council – Boy Scouts of America for their work and fundraising efforts to save the Filer American Legion Hall. Thanks to these young leaders for their service and for leading by example. #PreparedForLife #BePrepared #DutyToOthers

The United States Department of Justice has committed to end Operation Choke Point, a program that was intended to target ‘high risk’ industries, but often resulted in wrongful discrimination against law-abiding businesses. This development is welcome news, and I intend to follow through to ensure that the entire Department, along with federal financial regulators who participated in the program, receive the message that this fundamentally flawed initiative is over and that the government must cease its unmeritorious prosecutions. https://www.crapo.senate.gov/media/newsreleases/crapo-receives-doj-commitment-to-end-operation-choke-point

The National Interagency Fire Center reports 8 currently active wildfires in Idaho affecting more than 140,000 acres.  Over 630,000 acres have already burned in 2,506 wildfires this year in Idaho alone.  I joined Senators Senator Ron Wyden, Senator Jim Risch and several of my other colleagues in sending a letter to Senate Leadership asking that any future disaster aid package include wildfire funding fix.
May we #NeverForget.

I joined my Senate colleagues in co-sponsoring a resolution commemorating the 70th birthday of the U.S. Air Force.  Founded in September 1947 following World War II, the Air Force has defended the U.S. through global vigilance, global reach and global power.  Founded at the same time as the reserve component, the Air National Guard also celebrates 70 years today.  Happy 70th Birthday, United States Air Force and Air National Guard!  A special thank you to Idaho’s Mountain Home Air Force Base Gunfighters and 124th Fighter Wing at Gowen Field for your dedicated service to our nation.

The Wildfire Mitigation Assistance Act, of which I am a co-sponsor, would allow fire-prone communities to apply for Hazard Mitigation grants through the Federal Emergency Management Agency in order to undertake ‘fire-wise' projects for homes in the wildland urban interface or to reduce hazardous fuels.  Congress must continue to pursue efforts aimed at reducing the risk and severity of wildfires, as well as improve the response, prevention and mitigation efforts. http://www.ktvb.com/news/politics/western-senators-fight-to-change-how-fires-are-funded/482939273

For those who have experienced any form of sexual assault or harassment, I support you.  I hear your echoes of solidarity with one another—as well as the silence of those suffering quietly.  Though we must continue to do all we can to ensure victims have access to the help they need, we all have a responsibility to speak out and to stop these kinds of acts before they happen.  Everyone deserves the safety and security of person.  As I have supported through legislation like the Violence Against Women Act in the past, I will continue to support efforts that connect victims with appropriate response resources, as well as efforts and conversations to prevent further assaults and violence from happening in the future.  #MeTooEndsWithMe

President Donald J. Trump signed into law a bill that will nullify the CFPB’s controversial rule promoting class action litigation over arbitration in financial resolution disputes. The CFPB’s rule threatened to drive up costs for the millions of Americans who carry a credit card or use other financial products. Because Congress stepped in to nullify the rule, consumers will continue to have access to quick, inexpensive and efficient mechanisms of dispute resolution.

Representative Hansen demonstrated a high standard of service to the people of Idaho, and I join with all of Idaho in sending comfort and peace to his family at this challenging time. He was a strong leader and represented Idaho well during his tenure in the U.S. House of Representatives, whether it was helping shape the growth of what became the Idaho National Laboratory, or preserving our heritage and work on our public lands. His legacy will be fondly remembered here in Idaho. On a personal note, I served an internship with Representative Hansen when I was in college in the 1970s, and it helped spur my interest in the political process and public service.

#ICYMI – I joined senators from both sides of the aisle to introduce a financial regulatory reform package. These bipartisan proposals will significantly improve our financial regulatory framework and foster economic growth by right-sizing regulation, particularly for smaller financial institutions and community banks. Read more: https://www.politico.com/story/2017/11/13/senate-banking-rules-244857

Today, the Senate Finance Committee continued its bipartisan, regular order markup of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.  I participated by asking Tom Barthold, chief of staff of the non-partisan Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT), a series of questions.  The JCT reports show that taxes will go down for every single income category in America.  My questioning further explored the JCT analysis that a reduction in the corporate tax rate does not just benefit CEOs and wealthy stockholders, as some may incorrectly think.  In fact, JCT has confirmed that, most definitely, individual American workers benefit from a reduction in the corporate tax rate, through the resulting higher wages and greater job opportunities, through increased values for their pensions and other retirement funds (which are now making up an ever-increasing share of corporate equity), and through increased values of the individual stocks they may own in the company they work for.

The Senate’s passage of the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) yesterday signals our commitment to our military men and women and their families and ensures properly devoted resources to their needs at home and abroad.  Mountain Home Air Force Base and the Idaho National Guard at Gowen Field will both see direct improvements from this year’s NDAA that will help enhance their strategic military missions.  I am committed to ensuring that the brave men and women serving our country have the resources they need to protect our country, while also remaining accountable to the American taxpayer.

Thank you to Idaho’s over 150,000 small businesses for employing over 96% of the Idaho workforce!

76 years ago today, the Japanese Imperial Navy launched a surprise military strike against the U.S.  On this 76th anniversary of that “date which will live in infamy,” we remember the lives lost and the heroism of the many women and men who defended our freedoms in World War II.  #PearlHarbor76

In addition to the attacks on Pearl Harbor, we also remember civilian employees, including many Idahoans, working for Morrison Knudsen Company building infrastructure on Wake Island when it was attacked the same day as Pearl Harbor.  They held the island for weeks against overwhelming odds, were killed or captured as prisoners of war and became lasting examples of resolve.  Thank you to those who served on Wake Island and their families for all they have given to our country. Earlier this year, I had the pleasure of presenting this Congressional Record Statement to family members of those who served on Wake Island.  The last worker from Idaho, Joe Goicoechea, passed away this past year.  May their heroism never be forgotten.
